## Predicting Covid-19 outbreaks using multi-layer centrality measures

### Preprint 

<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14767"> <i class="bi bi-file-earmark-text-fill"></i> View on arXiv</a> | <a href="https://github.com/christine-hvw/thesis_disclosed/tree/publication"> <i class="bi bi-github"></i> View on Github</a>

:::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
<img src="resources/fig_analysis.png" style="width:420px; margin-top: 40px"/>
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
<img src="resources/fig_cox.png" style="width:370px; clip-path: inset(5px 5px 5px 5px); margin-left:40px"/>
:::
::::

In this study, we leverage the framework of multi-layer networks to model and predict the spread of COVID-19 in the Dutch population. We compare different centrality measures in their predictive ability of individual infections. The centrality measures are employed as predictors in proportional-hazards and XGBoost models, and we find that Eigenvector centrality can account for substantial variation in infection risks and timing. The study originated from my master thesis at the Departmet of Methodology and Statistics at Utrecht University.

## Mapping Missions: New Data for the Study of African History

- **Article:** Hedde-von Westernhagen, C., & Becker, B. (2022). Mapping Missions: New Data for the Study of African History, Research Data Journal for the Humanities and Social Sciences, 7(1), 1-33. doi: <https://doi.org/10.1163/24523666-bja10027>
- **Dataset:** <https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/E9EEMQ>

:::: columns
::: {.column width="70%"}
<img src="https://brill.com/view/journals/rdj/7/1/24523666_007_01_s007_text_f0001.jpg" style="height:450px"/>
:::

::: {.column width="30%"}
<img src="https://brill.com/view/journals/rdj/7/1/24523666_007_01_s007_text_f0002.jpg" style="height:450px; margin-left:-90px"/>
:::
::::

<br>

This project originated from my bachelor thesis in Political Science at University of Bremen. After digitizing a new map on the locations of Christian mission stations in Africa, we investigated how this map differs from the commonly used sources in historical social research. You can find a synthesis of the findings in this [Twitter thread](https://twitter.com/christinehvw/status/1611399297215467520?s=20&t=t9RRozfdTrFfYvBRIKLVOA).

As a data science volunteer for the NGO [CorrelAid](https://correlaid.org) <img src="resources/caid_c.png" style="height:20px;margin-top:-7px">, I gave a workshop on network analysis in R (and Python) to my peers. ## Co-authorship network of the *SOCIUM* research center

### Data collection

<a href="https://github.com/christine-hvw/coauthr_net-socium"> <i class="bi bi-github"></i> View on Github</a>

During my Bachelor's at the University of Bremen, I assembled a dataset of co-authorship relations within the local social science institute SOCIUM.


### Working paper

<a href="https://github.com/christine-hvw/socium_coauthorship"> <i class="bi 
bi-github"></i> View on Github</a>

<img src=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/christine-hvw/socium_coauthorship/main/figures/plot_nw-1.png?raw=true" style="height:450px;"/>

<br>

As part of a summer school course at Radboud University Nijmegen, I returned to this dataset for the implementation of a temporal exponential random graph model (TERGM). I try to explain the temporal emergence of the co-authorhsip network over 10 years, using author attributes and internal network measures.
